article_title: Workers look for safe haven after the boom
article_text:
Workers look for safe haven after the boom Employees study options as cuts continue in energy-related sectors

Photo: Elizabeth Conley, Staff Amanda Salazar works in her office at Memorial Hermann on Friday,...

Amanda Salazar worked eight years at National Oilwell Varco. By last fall, she says, it was clear that job losses in energy and related fields would only accelerate.

article_metadata.description: On Friday, state employment officials reported further cuts in mining and logging, the sector that includes most energy jobs, and said that major slice of the workforce is 16.5 percent smaller than it was a year ago.  While the new Texas Workforce Commission report said the Houston region added 10,100 jobs overall in February, University of Houston economist Bill Gilmer's seasonally adjusted data show a loss of 4,400 jobs in the first two months of the year.  The regional unemployment number dipped slightly in February to 4.7 percent, from 4.8 percent the previous month, but Jankowski suspects that doesn't include people who may have decided to go back to school, retire early or take a break from working after being laid off.  Education, health care and leisure and hospitality kept Houston's overall job numbers in the black in February, but economists say those sectors are riding the momentum of population growth sparked by the oil and gas boom.  Tanya Cook, vice president of talent acquisition for Memorial Hermann, said the hospital system is still bringing on 400 to 500 new employees each month to fill positions as it expands with new and existing hospitals.  [...] as generous health care benefit plans expire with layoffs and population growth drops off, economists think the effects of the oil slump will reach that sector as well.  [...] the 4.5 percent year-over-year growth reported in education and health services in February was slightly slower rate during the two previous months.  [...] those that cater to business lunches and after-work events are seeing belt-tightening.  [...] the rig count turns around and oil climbs above $50 a barrel, Jankowski doubts Houston will see relief.
article_metadata.author.name: By Sarah Scully
